Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cybercrime Susceptibility in the Sociotechnical System: Exploration of Integrated Micro- and Macro-Level Sociotechnical Models of Cybersecurity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a holistic approach to sociotechnical system security that combines innovations in both criminology and engineering/computer science. We design unified sociotechnical security models that capture how sociotechnical intrusions against social as well as technical aspects of the system (i.e., modeled as hidden sequences of system security states) result in observed hard data such as security sensor alerts and soft data produced by human/social sensors such as reports about slow machines.

To model the social aspect of the sociotechnical security models, (1) we collect extensive social survey data from one specific subpopulation (employees) nested within one sociotechnical system (the university campus); (2) we identify various social and social-psychological factors reducing susceptibility to victimization by computer-focused crime drawing on several criminological and sociological theories; (3) we supplement social survey data with organizational-level data to explore influences of characteristics of organizational units on individual-level employee victimization by computer-focused crimes as well as rates of such cybercrime threats in organizational units. We analyze the collected data by applying unique integrated sociotechnical analytical approaches that encapsulate the adversarial actions and subsequent rewards/costs using stochastic Markov decisions processes and probabilistic data production models.

Our research provides guidelines for other researchers looking to incorporate social science methods and models into engineering systems, with the criminological/sociological aspect of the study of use to many other researchers. This work will transform how researchers approach the problem of sociotechnical security, in that our holistic view cognizant of both social and technical factors will become widespread.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed research investigated the foundation for a holistic approach to sociotechnical system security that uses innovations in both criminology and engineering/computer science. It develops computational models engendering the automated estimation and prediction of the system security state, which is a function of both technical and social engineering attack tactics. In particular, this research constructs a sociotechnical cybersecurity model. In particular, we achieved the following goals:

1- Collected comprehensive social data. This project started by collecting extensive social data related to victimization by computer-focused cybercrimes (e.g., various technical intrusions and social-engineering attacks) through a survey of specific subpopulation (employees) within one sociotechnical system (the University of Miami Coral Gables campus) that utilized state-of-the-art techniques for conducting surveys. The survey included questions developed based on known criminological theories such as the self-control and routine activities theories and two contemporary sociological theoretical frameworks, social exchange theory and a social network perspective, to understand how characteristics such as computer knowledge and skills, usage patterns, levels of self-regulation, trust, reciprocity, commitment, risk-aversion, and also an individual’s position and status within a social network, may affect computer-based crime victimization.

2- Utilizing organizational-level data. Data from organizational units were used for examining questions regarding the influence of organizational unit-level structural and institutional factors on susceptibility to cybercrime and their relative importance of in predicting cyber threats. To address these questions and model and analyze the survey and organizational data, individual and macro-level models and multi-level models that draw upon rigorous statistical methods are built. 3-Integrating social and technical models. 

3- We have taken initial steps to combine our findings in cyber security systems solutions. In particular, we use software defined networks to allow non-technical (and potentially susceptible) users to have more control over their computing assets and private data. They can define policies for their data and computers in terms of who can access them in what context. This reduces the attack surface against various adversarial exploits remarkably. This effort is supported by this NSF EAGER project as well as DHS S&T. More technically, the presented design provides the ability to create network tunnels on demand between devices that reside in different networks, the ability to dynamically create new connections between devices based either on local application generated traffic or remote services requests and security aspects as device authentication and network traffic confidentiality.
